title: Humanitarian Relief and Conflict Response in Interdisciplinary and Applied Perspectives.
abstractText:
Since the end of the Cold War, the global aid industry has experienced the dual pressures of rapid growth accompanied by a significant expansion in both the roles it is expected to fulfil and the range of tasks it has attempted to perform. In order to explore these challenges the seminar will be structured around six themes over 18 months, each taking the shape of a day long workshop. The key themes identified by the applicants relate to contemporary practical and theoretical issues arising from relief work.

The workshops will be structured around key concepts and categories such as Conflict, Intervention and the Politics of knowledge, Darfur: Assessing the Assessments; Emergency in Haiti: Where Medics, Missionaries and Militaries Collide; Assessing humanitarianism: disaster and data dissemination; Who are the humanitarians now?

These workshops are open to the public and bring together academics, practitioners, lay public and people from the areas concerned. The records (including film footage and presentations) of these events can be found on the HCRI website.
impactText:
This research and NHGO engagement seminar has been productive. The work has been integtrated to the HealthCare under Fire campaign of MSF and has led to a joint publication in June 2014 (Revue internationale de la Croix Rouge).
A joint initiative with SAVE the Children has also been brought about from this seminar. This has led to a joint Post Doc Appointment between HCRI and SCF in November 2014. Other Policy & public services
findingsText: The seminar series has had the desired impact - namely it has enabled the Humanitarian and Conflict Response Institute set a research agenda and establish vital contacts with the NGO world. The NGOs involved were: MSF, British Red Cross, MAG, and Handicap International in particular. The research project established common ground for further research and brought about new collaborations. This collaboration was primarily an initial exchange of ideas between practitioners and academics. It has enabled joint research projects to emerge and collaborative networks to become established and active. This is undoubtedly part of a wider change in the humanitarian sector which brings together researchers and practitioners. This was primarily a seminar series with limited aims, It nevertheless generated some research outputs but it also led directly to collaborations and further research meetings: namely a Memorandum of Understanding with the Federation of the Red Cross, a strong collaboration and joint bid with the HPG of the Overseas Development Institute, further collaboration with MSF (France and International). It also served a seed for a major conference, Humanitarianism,, past, present, future held in October 2012 and an AHRC network led by colleagues in Birmingham.
